item.title: Kicksecure /etc/hostname /etc/hosts
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
This will be fixed after updates.

(The following file will solve it.)

github.com

Kicksecure/kicksecure-network-conf/blob/master/etc/NetworkManager/conf.d/20_kicksecure-network-conf.conf

## Copyright (C) 2022 - 2022 ENCRYPTED SUPPORT LP <adrelanos@whonix.org>
## See the file COPYING for copying conditions.

## fixes `hostname` showing `localhost.localdomain` instead of `localhost`
## which can lead to issues.
##
## The hostname is set to `localhost` in `/etc/hostname` already in VMs anyhow.
## However, NetworkManager considers that an invalid hostname and therefore changes it.
## Therefore NetworkManager hostname management is disabled here.
##
## There is no indication that this is security critical.
## The user is free to undo this setting.
##
## This is useful in redistributed (downloadable) Kicksecure VMs.
## This might not be needed or useful in different VMs (such as on a VPS) or
## the host operating system.
##
## https://forums.whonix.org/t/kicksecure-etc-hostname-etc-hosts/10919
[main]
hostname-mode=none

item.title: Kicksecure /etc/hostname /etc/hosts
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Related to network manager…

Quote NetworkManager.conf(5) — network-manager — Debian bullseye-backports — Debian Manpages

hostname-mode

Set the management mode of the hostname. This parameter will affect only the transient hostname. If a valid static hostname is set, NetworkManager will skip the update of the hostname despite the value of this option. An hostname empty or equal to ‘localhost’, ‘localhost6’, ‘localhost.localdomain’ or ‘localhost6.localdomain’ is considered invalid.

item.title: Kicksecure /etc/hostname /etc/hosts
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Now I remember why I didn’t want to add files /etc/hostname and /etc/hosts into packages. This is because for Kicksecure we’ll be needing to rely distro morphing installation method for the server use case for a while. Users using VPS will probably have no other chance than telling their VPS provider to install Debian and then sudo apt install kicksecure-cli. In that case, the installed packages shouldn’t modify the server’s existing /etc/hostname and /etc/hosts. Therefore for Kicksecure builds, these files need to be auto generated during the build process so that these aren’t managed by any packages.

Read full topic

item.title: Kicksecure /etc/hostname /etc/hosts
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
I don’t want to add this by default. Not sure you suggested that but in case if anyone interprets it as such as suggestion, here’s why.

Patrick:

I wonder where Debian is getting the .localdomain part from anyhow? It is nowhere to be found in folder /etc.

This long thread and who knows where it even started looks rather complicated:

lists.debian.org

debian-devel Oct 2005 by thread

Might argue somewhere against .localdomain such as here:

lists.debian.org

Re: localhost.localdomain

Since some modification must be shipped anyhow, and since there is no generic default / convention for default host name, can as well as also add a “proper” hostname, i.e. not localhost.

Will probably use same settings in Kicksecure as in Whonix. I.e. default hostname host.

github.com

Whonix/whonix-base-files/blob/master/etc/hostname.whonix

host
github.com

Whonix/whonix-base-files/blob/master/etc/hosts.whonix

## Copyright (C) 2012 - 2020 ENCRYPTED SUPPORT LP <adrelanos@riseup.net>
## See the file COPYING for copying conditions.

#### meta start
#### project Whonix
#### category networking and dns
#### description
## Debian default /etc/hosts + Anonymity Distribution specific additions.
##
## Currently only <code>127.0.0.1 host.localdomain host</code> gets added.
#### meta end

## Anonymity Distribution /etc/hosts

## Defaults
127.0.0.1       localhost
::1             localhost ip6-localhost ip6-loopback
fe00::0         ip6-localnet
ff00::0         ip6-mcastprefix
ff02::1         ip6-allnodes
This file has been truncated. show original

I.e. package kicksecure-base-files effectively shipping files:

  • /etc/hostname
  • /etc/hosts

Unless there are better suggestions for default hostname / hosts file / implementation details.

item.title: Kicksecure /etc/hostname /etc/hosts
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Apparently there is no real default hostname. By Debian default, /etc/hostname and /etc/hosts is not managed by any package. For Debian installations that file is generated by Debian installer.

serverfault.com

Where can I get the default /etc/hosts file for Debian Sid?

debian, sid
asked by Eugene Yarmash on 11:00PM - 15 Jul 12 UTC
GitLab

netcfg-common.c · 1.158 · Debian Installer / netcfg

Repository imported from https://anonscm.debian.org/git/d-i/netcfg.git/

GitLab

netcfg.h · 1.158 · Debian Installer / netcfg

Repository imported from https://anonscm.debian.org/git/d-i/netcfg.git/

I thought by writing localhost into /etc/hostname during Kicksecure build process could be avoided to have /etc/hostname or /etc/hosts managed by any package in Kicksecure. And then later user can just customize it if needed. But that does not work…

TNT_BOM_BOM:

sudo: unable to resolve host localhost.localdomain: Name or service not known

Even though /etc/hosts by default (as created by grml-debootstrap)…

github.com

grml/grml-debootstrap/blob/master/chroot-script#L430

    

  1.        else
  2.          echo root:"$a" | chpasswd $CHPASSWD_OPTION
  3.          unset a
  4.          unset b
  5.        fi
  6.      done
  7.   fi
  8. }
  9. # }}}
  11. # set up /etc/hosts {{{
  12. hosts() {
  13.   if ! [ -f /etc/hosts ] ; then
  14.      cat > /etc/hosts << EOF
  15. 127.0.0.1       localhost
  16. ::1             localhost ip6-localhost ip6-loopback
  17. ff02::1         ip6-allnodes
  18. ff02::2         ip6-allrouters

  20.   fi
  21. }
    22.

Already contains:

127.0.0.1       localhost

Other VM creation tools (example: https://grml.org/grml-debootstrap/) set /etc/hostname to something (example: grml).

I wonder where Debian is getting the .localdomain part from anyhow? It is nowhere to be found in folder /etc.
